title: For Sale:  Gripes and Advice
postcontent:
Gripes:

Has anyone else noticed that the best prices for green tips and SKS rifles is at dealer shops?  In all honesty, and paper trail concerns aside, who wants to pay someone over 500 for an SKS that a dealer will sell for less than 400 plus tax?  Some people (just some) are listing brush guns at safe queen prices.

Also, when did all mosins start at 200 bucks?  I can see 200 for a nicer example, but I don't want to pay a premium for Ho Chi Minh's back up drop piece.  

Lastly, I don't shoot 223, but I did I'd take all my green tips and trade them for a substantially greater quantity of plain jane FMJ.  There is no such thing as a magic bullet, and if you really think things are going to get that bad, then you should stack deep any ammo that will reliably run in your weapon (cheapest price gets you the most rounds).

Advice:

The premium one might pay for a "soon to be [maybe] banned" type of ammunition could instead be spent on spare magazines, range time, replacement parts for weapons (springs, extractors, etc) or other items for gun maintenance.  I know people are stocking ammo, but who's stocking cleaning supplies, mag springs, gas tubes and the like?  If there is concern over certain guns being banned, isn't what's in your parts bin as important as what's in your gun safe?

There has been some discussion on "paper trails" with purchasing from Midway or other places using your credit card.  What do you think using Armslist creates?  Does anyone email you asking if you "still have it" and then you never hear from them again?  That could be someone seeing who you are.  Do you use an anon email address? Your IP address doesn't lie.  If I were truly concerned about the paper trail, I'd list that I had an unspecified amount, take emails from serious buyers, and talk on the telephone (or better yet meet in person somewhere). That is the way to avoid a paper trail as a buyer or seller and you are legally taking steps to maintain your privacy.  Better yet, put on your tinfoil hat, march down to Starbucks and use their Wifi.  Problem solved.

It is a sub- compact, 9mm, polymer frame handgun that uses a locked breach system referred to as "Safe Action". This is the combination of a trigger safety, firing pin safety and drop safety that render the loaded pistol incapable of firing, even when banged or bumped, unless someone actually squeezes the trigger. Because it does not have a hammer, the spring loaded striker (firing pin) is technically blocked off, partially retracted and not in geometric alignment with a chambered cartridge.
